channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Trump’s Embrace, Saudis Brace for a Chillier Tone From Biden
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s leaders counted on President Trump’s unwavering support, but President-elect Biden has vowed to take away the kingdom’s “dangerous blank check.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Reema bint Bandar bin Sultan, Princess of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: “America will never again check its principles at the door just to buy oil or sell weapons,” President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said during the campaign.

item.title: How Steve Bannon and a Chinese Billionaire Created a Right-Wing Coronavirus Media Sensation
item.description: Increasingly allied, the American far right and members of the Chinese diaspora tapped into social media to give a Hong Kong researcher a vast audience for peddling unsubstantiated pandemic claims.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Vivian Wang and Danny Hakim

item.title: A Holocaust Survivor Lifts Neighbors in Dark Times
item.description: Simon Gronowski escaped the Nazis as a child and went on to write and speak widely about his experiences. In April, he began brightening lives by playing jazz tunes from his apartment window.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Gronowski at his home in Belgium.

item.title: Under a Divisive Peace, Wartime Rifts Hobble Hope in Bosnia
item.description: The Dayton Accords, which ended fighting in the country 25 years ago, created a dysfunctional system that put power in the hands of politicians stoking ethnic division.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cemetery in the village of Kevljani in northern Bosnia and Herzegovina that was the site of a mass grave during the war in the country in the 1990s.

item.title: Bobi Wine, Uganda Opposition Leader, Released From Jail
item.description: Two days after police took him into custody, presidential contender Bobi Wine resurfaced on Friday in court where he was charged with flouting coronavirus rules and released.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Bobi Wine walking to court on Thursday in Iganga, Uganda.

item.title: A City Put Up Candle-Like Christmas Lights. ‘Some People See Other Things.’
item.description: The Belgian city of Oudenburg’s holiday display has made international headlines for the wrong reasons.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier

item.title: She Helped South Korea in Its Time of Need. In the Pandemic, It Repaid Her.
item.description: Decades ago, a young American woman served an impoverished South Korea as a Peace Corps volunteer. Now the country is an economic powerhouse, and it decided to send her a token of its gratitude. ​
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Sandra Nathan teaching a class in South Korea in the late 1960s as a Peace Corps volunteer.

item.title: Abolitionist Is Earliest Black Londoner Honored With Blue Plaque
item.description: Ottobah Cugoano, who became a writer and campaigner after surviving slavery in the West Indies, has been honored by a heritage program that long focused on white men.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the many blue plaques dotted on buildings around London to commemorate the lives of notable inhabitants.

item.title: A Lie and a Pizza Shop: Why Australian Officials Reversed a Lockdown
item.description: South Australia imposed tight statewide restrictions based on what a man had said about his relationship to a restaurant. And then the authorities learned the truth.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Mike Ives
item.media:description: At a test site in Adelaide, South Australia, on Tuesday. A lockdown in the state was partly triggered by a man who “deliberately misled” contact tracers, the authorities said.

item.title: Margaret Guilfoyle, Trailblazing Australian Lawmaker, Dies at 94
item.description: As a member of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser’s cabinet from 1975 to 1983, Ms. Guilfoyle was the first woman to run an Australian government department.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett
item.media:description: Margaret Guilfoyle in 1975 while she was minister for education.

item.title: Boris Johnson, Seen as a Trump Ally, Signals Alignment With Biden
item.description: The prime minister wants to show that Britain remains a vital ally. On climate change and military spending, he is promising major steps that will be welcomed by the president-elect.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Jessica Taylor/UK Parliament, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressing Parliament in a video call on Thursday. He is self-isolating after being exposed to the coronavirus.

item.title: South Africa and Malawi Quarrel Over Fate of Shepherd Bushiri, a Fugitive Preacher
item.description: Shepherd Bushiri, the founder of a megachurch in South Africa, fled to his home country, Malawi, amid fraud and money laundering charges, leaving the two nations to argue over his fate.
item.dc:creator: Monica Mark
item.media:credit: Wikus De Wet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shepherd Bushiri at an event held in a stadium in Soweto, South Africa, in January. His church has at least a million followers in South Africa alone, he says, with branches in several other African countries.

item.title: Egypt Arrests Human Rights Leader, Continuing Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: The head of a human rights group and two of its other staff members have joined thousands of opposition figures, protesters and activists already in prison.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi in February. Mr. el-Sisi’s government has silenced most dissent over the past six years.

item.title: Toronto's Van Killing Case Goes to Trial
item.description: Two years after a man drove a rental van down a sidewalk, killing 10 and injuring 16, he has pleaded not criminally responsible because of the autism spectrum disorder.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cathy Riddell, a survivor of a 2018 van attack that claimed the lives of 10 people and injured 16, near the site of the attack in Toronto.

item.title: Should Canada Adopt #CovidZero?
item.description: Some scientists say that the country should aim to get the infection rate as close to zero as possible. Atlantic Canada may show how it’s done.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Nunavut entered a two-week mandatory restriction period to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Dr. Fauci Sees ‘Terribly Painful Months’ Ahead
item.description: How we should think about the holidays, and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Adam Pasick

item.title: Jonathan Pollard, Convicted Spy, Completes Parole and May Move to Israel
item.description: The former Navy intelligence analyst served 30 years in prison for stealing American secrets during the Cold War. Some of them ultimately ended up with the Soviet government.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Jonathan J. Pollard, a former Navy intelligence analyst, gave a range of classified information to Israel.

item.title: Senator Rick Scott of Florida is the latest member of Congress to test positive.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Senator Rick Scott of Florida, at a campaign rally for two Republican Senate candidates in Georgia last week.

item.title: A lie and a pizza joint: Why Australian officials reversed a lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: David Mariuz/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An empty street in Adelaide on Thursday during a lockdown in the state of South Australia.

item.title: With federal assistance programs in doubt, millions of Americans face financial hardship.
item.dc:creator: Nelson D. Schwartz, Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Nic Coury for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Salinas, Calif., members of the National Guard provided assistance this month at a food bank, which saw a massive increase in requests for assistance.

item.title: The Patriarch of the Serbian Orthodox Church dies after presiding over a packed funeral.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Serbian Orthodox Church Patriarch Irinej in Belgrade in March.

item.title: What You Need to Know Today
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: A Chinese drugmaker reports progress on a vaccine candidate.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: People participating in a large-scale trial of the Sinopharm coronavirus vaccine in August in Manama, Bahrain.

item.title: The W.H.O. rejects the antiviral drug remdesivir as a Covid-19 treatment.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey
item.media:description: Vials of the antiviral drug remdesivir at a Gilead manufacturing site in the United States.

item.title: Fighting the virus, the University of Michigan battens down the hatches.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:description: William O’Brien, a Michigan freshman, and his mother, Karen O’Brien, packed up his dorm room on Monday. About 3,000 students will be allowed back into university housing.

item.title: Trump officials object, but school doors are closing across the country.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: With schools closed again in New York, Nicole Subran, a Brooklyn resident, has no one to look after her children.

item.title: A senior Defense Department official is infected with the virus, and others were exposed.
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ-Roll Call, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Anthony J. Tata, who tested positive for the coronavirus, will isolate at home for the next 14 days, the Defense Department said.

item.title: 1945: Britain Asks for Whiskey to Ensure ‘Merry, Merry Christmas’
item.description: For the first peacetime Christmas after World War II, a British newspaper called for whiskey usually exported to America to be kept aside to boost people’s spirits at home.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Amid the Coronavirus Pandemic, a Battle Emerges Over Green Spaces
item.description: A need for parks during lockdown has turned into a debate about the future of inner-city golf courses.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Northcote golf course in Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Boris Johnson, Coronavirus, Mike Pompeo: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Coronavirus case rates fall across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: World Health Organization Rejects Antiviral Drug Remdesivir as Covid-19 Treatment
item.description: In a review of several trials, the World Health Organization found that Gilead’s drug did not improve survival rates for patients nor did it help them recover.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey
item.media:description: Remdesivir was authorized for emergency use last spring, a move that baffled some experts.

item.title: Jan Myrdal, Swedish Author and Provocateur, Dies at 93
item.description: His father and mother were both Nobel Prize winners. His most famous book was about how badly they had treated him.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The author Jan Myrdal in 1991. Nothing in his career garnered him as much attention as a book he wrote expressing his distaste for his parents, the Nobel Prize winners Gunnar and Alva Myrdal.

item.title: Booker Prize 2020: Douglas Stuart Wins for 'Shuggie Bain'
item.description: The autobiographical novel, about the lonely gay son of an alcoholic mother in 1980s Scotland, was one of four debut books in this year’s shortlist.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Douglas Stuart won the 2020 Booker Prize for his debut novel “Shuggie Bain,” which has drawn comparisons to D.H. Lawrence, James Joyce and Frank McCourt.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: An Australian unit’s “disgraceful” conduct in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry and Dani Blum
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Australia’s defense chief, Angus Campbell, said on Thursday that the military “unreservedly” apologized to the Afghan people.

item.title: As the U.S. nears the 200,000 daily case mark, Americans are urged to avoid Thanksgiving travel.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin, Karen Zraick, Michael D. Shear, Michael Gold and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday issued a warning against holiday travel.

item.title: Dutch Police Urge Public to Stop ‘Pedo-Hunting’ After Vigilante Violence
item.description: A man’s death in the Netherlands last month after an attack by a group of teenagers has prompted the authorities to clamp down on vigilantism.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sem Van Der Wal/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourners gathered for a memorial for a retired teacher who was killed in Arnhem, the Netherlands, this month.

item.title: The culling of minks in Denmark prompts a political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Erdbrink and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Farmers loading a truck with culled minks from their farm near Naestved, Denmark, this month.

item.title: Deadly Protests Erupt in Uganda After Arrest of 2 Opposition Figures
item.description: At least 16 people were killed in protests over the arrests. One of the detained presidential candidates, the popular musician-turned-lawmaker Bobi Wine, was accused of breaking coronavirus restrictions at campaign rallies.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A supporter of the presidential candidate Bobi Wine was among those detained in the district of Luuka, Uganda, on Wednesday. Protesters were demonstrating against the candidate’s arrest.

item.title: Dublin Zoo Pleaded for Pandemic Help. Supporters Gave $1.2 Million in Hours.
item.description: The zoo, a popular tourist spot that’s regarded as a national treasure, warned that it might have to close permanently as Ireland endures its second coronavirus lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Visitors arriving at Dublin Zoo after it reopened in June. It closed again in October, when Ireland imposed a new coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Virus Words vs. Actions
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Students attend virtual classes once in-person learning resumed in August in Phoenix.

item.title: States that imposed few restrictions now have the worst outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby and Rich Harris
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Des Moines this week. Iowa is one of several states to recently impose a mask mandate for the first time.

item.title: They Championed Venezuela’s Revolution. They Are Now Its Latest Victims.
item.description: In an effort to complete his consolidation of power, Nicolás Maduro is cracking down on the leftist activists who once supported him, but have begun to speak up against his administration’s corruption and cronyism.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Tibisay Romero, Sheyla Urdaneta and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

item.title: Jordan, once a model of virus control, is now a hot spot.
item.dc:creator: Rana F. Sweis
item.media:description: A market in Amman, Jordan, before a five-day lockdown earlier this month.

item.title: UNICEF warns of a ‘lost generation’ and finds school closures are ineffective.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: At a school in Barcelona, Spain, in September.

item.title: Japan, facing a third wave, goes on ‘maximum alert’ as new infections reach record highs.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Commuters packed Shinagawa Station in Tokyo on Thursday, as the government announced that it was raising the alert level.

item.title: The Pacific island nation of Samoa records its first case of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A village in Samoa last year. The country had been one of the last in the world without a recorded coronavirus case.

item.title: Remote-only learning returns to New York City schools.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Rosa
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students leaving Public School 110 in Corona, Queens, on Wednesday. New York City’s schools had been open for in-person instruction for just under eight weeks.

item.title: Pompeo Visits West Bank Settlement and Calls B.D.S. Anti-Semitic
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the boycott-Israel movement would be treated as anti-Semitic, and ordered that imports from Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank be labeled products of Israel.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, left, visited the Golan Heights on Thursday, making him the most senior U.S. official to visit the area along Israel’s frontier with Syria.

item.title: A Chinese County Aims to Curb Dog Walking by Threatening to Kill the Dog
item.description: Restrictions on dogs are common in China. But one county’s plans to uniformly ban dog walking and kill the pets of rule-breaking owners has shocked the internet.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Taking dogs for a walk along the Yangtze River in Wuhan, China. The country has more than five million pet dogs.

item.title: Seeking Restart With Biden, Palestinians Eye End to Prisoner Payments
item.description: The Palestinian Authority pays stipends to prisoners held by Israel in a system critics call “pay to slay.” The worse the crime, the higher the payment.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., then the vice president, and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in Ramallah in 2010.

item.title: Covid Indoors: Scrubbing Surfaces Does Little to Mitigate Threat
item.description: Scientists who initially warned about contaminated surfaces now say that the virus spreads primarily through inhaled droplets, and that there is little to no evidence that deep cleaning mitigates the threat indoors.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: People buying disinfectant at a shopping mall in Hong Kong.

item.title: Covid-19, Boris Johnson, U.S. Troops: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Experts predict a forthcoming daily toll of 2,000 or more deaths daily.

item.title: Blood Lust and Demigods: Behind an Australian Force’s Slaughter of Helpless Afghans
item.description: The findings of a four-year military inquiry paint a brutal picture of a special forces culture of rewarding the killing of innocents and prisoners and methodically covering it up.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Australia’s military chief, Angus Campbell, said on Thursday that the military “unreservedly” apologized to the Afghan people.

item.title: Landslide in Ecuador Kills 5 at Illegal Mine
item.description: At least two more people were missing. The deaths, including that of a minor, occurred as the region was struggling to combat the illegal gold industry.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: A soldier patrolling a mining area in the village of Buenos Aires last year after a crackdown on illegal mining.

item.title: Wearing Masks to Prevent Coronavirus: Here's What Scientists Know
item.description: The accumulating research may be imperfect, and it’s still evolving, but the takeaway is simple. Right now, masks are necessary to slow the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: “The more people who wear a mask, the more the community is protected and therefore the more you individually benefit,” said a scientist.

item.title: Uganda Police Arrest Opposition Figure, Setting Off Deadly Protests
item.description: Three people died and 38 were injured in demonstrations that broke out after officers arrested Bobi Wine, a popular musician seeking the presidency in next year’s election.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Congo’s Latest Ebola Outbreak Declared Finished
item.description: The disease killed at least 55 people in an outbreak that began June 1, the 11th bout of Ebola to strike the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: Agence France-Presse

item.title: Kentucky closes its schools and bans indoor dining again as virus cases surge.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins and Will Wright
item.media:description: Gov. Andy Beshear said new restrictions were needed because of “exponential growth” in coronavirus infections in Kentucky.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A nationwide lockdown in France seems to be working.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Ex-Green Beret Admits He Betrayed U.S. While Spying for Russia
item.description: A former Army officer spied on the United States for more than a decade, providing Russians with sensitive information, prosecutors said. His treachery could land him in prison for life.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Rafael Dzibinski Debbins pleaded guilty in federal court in Northern Virginia to spying on the United States.

item.title: Mexico, Outraged at Arrest of Ex-Official Zepeda, Threatened to Toss U.S. Agents
item.description: Mexican officials made the threat after weeks of anger at the surprise arrest of a former defense minister. Their gambit appears to have worked — the charges were dropped.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Salvador Cienfuegos Zepeda was arrested after a multiyear inquiry that investigators called Operation Padrino or Godfather — a reference to what they claim was his nickname in the underworld.

item.title: Layers of Tragedy, in a Cemetery and in the Mountains
item.description: Armenians flee what they consider their historical home, after the end of a six-week war with Azerbaijan over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Armenian soldier at the military cemetery in Stepanakert, in Nagorno-Karabakh, near the graves of fallen comrades who died this fall during clashes with Azerbaijani troops.
